¿Dónde vives? (Where do you live?) Vivo en... (I live in...) 🏠 

 ¿De dónde eres? (Where are you from?) Soy de... (I am from...) 🍼

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn how to address people in different contexts

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
you (singular informal) 


Example

Me llamo Álvaro, ¿y tú?

My name is Álvaro, and you?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Me llamo Álvaro, ¿y tú?
contents.questionSub: By using "¿y tú?", Álvaro is addressing someone else.
contents.hints: Álvaro is addressing someone else with the question: "¿y tú?"

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: ______  eres María.
contents.hints: The word for "you" is "tú".

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText:
In Spain we mostly use "tú" in informal situations 
(e.g. with friends, family, people our own age) 
and with people we know well.
contents.englishText:
For more formal situations,
 we have another way of addressing people. 
Let's take a look!

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Vivo en Málaga, ¿y  ______
contents.hints: I live in Málaga, and you?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
you (singular formal) 

Example
Me llamo Susana, ¿y usted?
My name is Susana, and you?

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Yo vivo en Madrid, ¿y  ______  ?
contents.hints: I live in Madrid, and you?

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: In Spain, we mostly use "usted" in formal situations, with older people,
contents.englishText: with people we don't know, and to someone we want to show respect to.

contents.title: choose the correct answer
contents.question: Listen to the audio and choose the most appropriate situation.
contents.hints: This is a formal situation.

contents.title: choose the correct answer
contents.question: Imagine you're at a party with friends. What would you say?
contents.questionSub: Me llamo Alicia, ¿  ______
contents.hints: A party with friends would be an informal situation, so we'd use "tú"

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn how to speak formally

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
What's your name?

Example 
Buenos días, ¿cómo se llama?
Good morning, what's your name?

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Y usted, ¿cómo ______
contents.hints: We use "se llama" for "usted" (formal situations), and "te llamas" for "tú" (informal situations).

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: And what's your name?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
Where are you from?

Example 
Soy de Estados Unidos, ¿y usted? ¿De dónde es?
I'm from the US, and you? Where are you from?

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Soy de Estados Unidos, ¿y usted? ¿De dónde  ______  ?
contents.hints: I'm from the US, and you? Where are you from?

contents.title: Choose the correct answer
contents.question: You are meeting the CEO of a very important company. What would you ask her?
contents.hints: Are you from England or from the US?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
Where do you live?

Example 
Vivo en Barcelona, ¿y usted? ¿Dónde vive?
I live in Barcelona, and you? Where do you live?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Vivo en Barcelona, ¿y usted? ¿Dónde vive?
contents.questionSub: Silvia's asking someone she has a close relationship with.
contents.hints: She's using "usted" so she's in a very formal situation.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Improve your listening skills by following a audio

contents.title: Listen to the audio carefully..
contents.spanishText:
María: ¡Hola, buenos días! ¿Qué tal?
Peter: Buenos días, yo muy bien, ¿y usted?
María: Muy bien, gracias. Me llamo María, ¿y usted?
Peter: Yo soy Peter.
María: ¡Ah! ¿De dónde es, Peter? Yo soy de España.
Peter: Yo soy de Inglaterra, pero vivo en Madrid, ¿y usted?
María: ¡Ah! Yo también vivo en Madrid, pero soy de Barcelona.
Peter: Madrid es una ciudad fantástica, ¿eh?
María: Sí, ¡Madrid es fantástica!

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Soy Peter.
contents.questionSub: This sentence has the same meaning as: "Me llamo Peter".
contents.hints: Soy" followed by a name has the same meaning as "Me llamo..."

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Me llamo María, ¿y usted?
contents.questionSub: María is asking a question in an informal context.
contents.hints: She's using "usted" to address the other person, so it's a formal situation.

contents.title: Choose the correct answer
contents.question: Choose the option that best describes the audio.
contents.hints: María is from Spain and Peter is from England.
options: María es de España y Peter es de Inglaterra.
María vive en Barcelona y Peter vive en Madrid.
María es de Madrid y Peter es de Barcelona.
contents.correctAnswer: María es de España y Peter es de Inglaterra.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Yo también vivo en Madrid, pero soy de Barcelona.
contents.questionSub: María is originally from Madrid.
contents.hints: María says "Soy de Barcelona", so she is from Barcelona, but she lives in Madrid.

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: I also live in Madrid, but I'm from Barcelona.
contents.correctAnswer: Yo también, vivo, en, Madrid, pero soy, de, Barcelona.

contents.title: Choose the correct answer
contents.question: Choose the correct question to ask in an informal situation.
contents.questionSub: Vivo en Barcelona, ¿ _____
contents.hints: I live in Barcelona, and you?

contents.englishText: And you, how are you?

contents.question: Yo  ______  muy bien..
contents.hints: Yo estoy muy bien.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Y tú, ¿cómo  ______  ?
contents.hints: Y tú, ¿cómo estás?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Marta is very happy.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Pablo is very happy..

contents.title: Listen and select the correct word to fill the gap.
contents.question: ¿Cómo  ______  él?.
contents.hints: How is he?

contents.title: Arrange the words in the correct order.
contents.hints: She is a little bit tired.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Words like "yo" (I), "tú" (you singular), "él" (he) and "ella" (she) are called subject pronouns. When it's clear who we are talking about, we often skip them to sound more natural.
contents.englishText:
Yo estoy muy bien. (I'm very well.) - Estoy muy bien (I'm very well.)
¿Cómo estás tú? (How are you?) - ¿Cómo estás? (How are you?)

contents.title: True or false?

contents.questionSub: We can also just say "Estoy cansada".
contents.hints: True

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Yo estoy bien.
contents.questionSub: Luis is describing how he's feeling.
contents.hints: True

contents.title: Listen the audio carefully
contents.spanishText:
Pedro: ¡Hola! Buenos días.
Camarero: Buenos días, ¿qué quieren tomar?
Dani: Sí, un momento... Uno, dos, tres... Eh, cuatro cervezas, por favor.
contents.englishText:
Camarero: Muy bien, gracias.
Dani: ¿Ana, una cerveza para ti también?
Ana: No, gracias, para mí un café con leche.
Pedro: Y también dos bocadillos de queso. No, dos no, ¡tres bocadillos de queso, por favor!
Camarero: Perfecto, ¿algo más?
Dani: Sí, perdona, una copa de vino.

lessons.lessonTitle: Introduction to the gender of nouns
lessons.lessonSubTitle: Discover how nouns change based on the gender of the word

contents.title: Masculine or feminine?
contents.spanishText: As in many other languages, all nouns (words indicating people, animals, and objects) in Spanish have a gender. They can either be masculine or feminine.
contents.englishText:
masculine: amigo (male friend), bocadillo (sandwich)

feminine: amiga (female friend), cerveza (beer)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: amigo, bocadillo, amiga, cerveza
contents.questionSub: In Spanish, all words indicating people, animals, and objects have a gender.
contents.hints: These words have different genders; one way to tell is the different endings.

contents.title: Chose the correct answer
contents.question: What gender can nouns be in Spanish?
contents.hints: Spanish has only masculine and feminine genders, but other languages have more.

contents.title: Masculine or feminine?
contents.spanishText: Many masculine nouns end with the letter "o", whereas many feminine nouns end with the letter "a".
contents.englishText:
masculine: zapato (shoe), bocadillo (sandwich)

feminine: casa (house), tarta (cake)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: zapato, bocadillo
contents.questionSub: Many masculine nouns end with the letter "o".
contents.hints: Most Spanish masculine words end in "-o", but not all of them!

contents.title: Chose the correct answer
contents.question: Which letter do many feminine nouns end with?
contents.hints: Most Spanish feminine words end in '-a', but not all of them!

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: All the nouns you hear are masculine.
contents.hints: All the words you hear are feminine. They all end in "a": amiga (female friend), tarta (cake), casa (house).

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Some nouns do not end with "o" or "a".
contents.englishText: For instance cine (cinema) is masculine and estación (station) is feminine.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: cine, estación
contents.questionSub: Spanish nouns can end with other letters beside "o" and "a".
contents.hints: "Cine" is a masculine word but it ends in "-e", and "estación" is a feminine one but it ends in "-n".

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: In Spanish, most of the words we use to describe people change from singular to plural, depending on whether we're describing one person or more than one person.

Soy Marta, encantada. - Somos Marta y Elena, encantadas. (I'm Marta, nice to meet you. - We're Marta and Elena, nice to meet you.)

Soy colombiano. - Somos colombianos. (I'm Colombian. - We're Colombian.)

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn how words change depending on gender and number

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: An easy way of identifying a noun's gender is by looking at its article. In Spanish, the definite articles are "el, la, los, las" (the). We use "el" and "los" for masculine nouns and "la" and "las" for feminine nouns.
contents.englishText:
masculine: El hombre, el chico, el amigo, etc.

feminine: La mujer, la chica, la amiga, etc..

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el perro
contents.questionSub: The word in bold is masculine.
contents.hints: It's masculine because it has the article "el" and it ends in "-o".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: la casa
contents.questionSub: The word in bold is masculine.
contents.hints: We can see that "casa" is a feminine noun because its article is "la".

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We can also identify a noun's gender by looking at patterns in word endings. Here are some common ones to help you out. Nouns with the following endings are generally masculine:
contents.englishText:
nouns ending in -o: el amigo (the friend)

nouns ending in -n: el tren (the train)

nouns ending in -aje: el viaje (the trip)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el hotel
contents.questionSub: This noun is feminine.
contents.hints: This noun is masculine.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el viaje
contents.questionSub: This noun is masculine.
contents.hints: It's masculine because it has the article "el"; for feminine words we'd use "la".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: la ciudad
contents.questionSub: This noun is masculine.
contents.hints: This is a feminine noun.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: la lección
contents.questionSub: This noun is feminine.
contents.hints: All nouns ending in "-ción" are feminine and this word also has the article "la".

contents.englishText:
we practise...

Example
Mis amigos y yo practicamos español.
My friends and I practise Spanish.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Practicamos español con la app.
contents.questionSub: Irene is talking about just one person.
contents.hints: She uses "practicamos", which is the form for "nosotros/as".

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Raquel y yo   ______   inglés con Learn Spanish App.
contents.hints: Raquel y yo practicamos inglés con Learn Spanish App.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
you (plural) practise

Example
¿Practicáis español todos los días?
Do you practise Spanish every day?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Comprendo bien el español.
contents.questionSub: Berta is directly talking to a group of people.
contents.hints: She's talking to several people: she says "habláis" and "practicáis", both in the "vosotros" form.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Sandra, Luis... ¿vosotros   ______  inglés con libros o con la app de Learn Spanish?
contents.hints: Sandra, Luis... ¿vosotros practicáis inglés con libros o con la app de Learn Spanish?

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: Vosotros practicáis inglés con libros y con la app de Learn Spanish?
contents.correctAnswer: Vosotros, practicáis, inglés, con libros, y con, la app, de Learn Spanish

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn the "presente simple" of regular verbs

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: The most basic verb form is the one we call "infinitivo" (infinitive).
contents.englishText:
In Spanish we have three infinitive endings that indicate which group the verb belongs to: -ar, -er, -ir.

hablar (to speak)

leer (to read)

escribir (to write)

contents.title: Put the verbs in order belonging to the -ar group.
contents.hints: estudiar, hablar, practicar

contents.title: Put the verbs in order belonging to the -er group.
contents.hints: "Escribir" ends in -ir; "hablar" ends in -ar; "comprender" and "leer" both end in -er.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: escribir
contents.questionSub: This verb belongs to the -ar group
contents.hints: It belongs to the -ir group of verbs.

contents.title: Grammar: Regular verbs
contents.spanishText: The way we use regular verbs is by putting together the verb stem and the ending for the group (-ar, -er, -ir) the verb belongs to.
contents.englishText:
The stem is the infinitive without its ending:Infinitive -: stem

hablar -: habl-

leer -: le-

escribir -: escrib-

contents.title: Grammar: Regular verbs
contents.spanishText:
Regular verbs always follow the same pattern when we use them.

The below verbs are regular and they belong to the -ar ending group. They share the same ending for the first person singular "yo" (I):
contents.englishText:
hablar > -: (yo) habl-o 

 estudiar >  -: (yo) estudi-o

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: comprender
contents.questionSub: This is the verb stem of the verb "comprender".
contents.hints: The verb stem is: comprend-

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: "comprender", "leer"
contents.questionSub: These two verbs share the same tense endings
contents.hints: The verb stem is: comprend-

contents.title: Grammar: Regular verbs
contents.spanishText: Remember: in Spanish we use different endings depending on who performs the action:
contents.englishText:
yo escribo (I write) 

 tú escribes (you write)

contents.title: Grammar: Regular verbs
contents.spanishText: The endings shared by regular -ar verbs are:
contents.englishText:
Grammar: Personal pronouns :- Verb 

 Yo :- estudi-o

  Tú :- estudi-as

 Él / Ella / Usted :- estudi-a 

 Nosotros / Nosotras :- estudi-amos

 Vosotros / Vosotras :- estudi-áis

Ellos / Ellas / Ustedes :- estudi-an

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Hablo español y portugués.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: ¿  ______  turco?

contents.title: Complete the sentence.

contents.hints: Aleksander speaks Polish.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: ¿Qué  ______  hablas?

contents.question: Habla portugués muy bien.
contents.questionSub: In this sentence, Alex is talking about another person.
contents.hints: Alex uses the form "habla", which refers to "él" (he), "ella" (she) or "usted" (you formal).

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Luis, ¿  ______  libros en inglés o en español?
contents.hints: Luis, ¿lees libros en inglés o en español?

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: Sergio estudia mucho español y comprende bien esta lección.
contents.correctAnswer: Sergio estudia, mucho, español y, comprende bien, esta lección.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Raquel y yo   ______   inglés con Learn Spanish App.
contents.hints: Raquel y yo practicamos inglés con Learn Spanish App.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Sandra, Luis... ¿vosotros   ______  inglés con libros o con la app de Learn Spanish?
contents.hints: Sandra, Luis... ¿vosotros practicáis inglés con libros o con la app de Learn Spanish?

contents.title: Put the verbs in order belonging to the -er group.
contents.hints: "Escribir" ends in -ir; "hablar" ends in -ar; "comprender" and "leer" both end in -er.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn different professions and how to talk about yours

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: What is your job?

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Carmen, ¿  ______  qué  ______  ?
contents.hints: Carmen, ¿en qué trabajas?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the teacher 


Example

Yo soy profesora de inglés.

I'm an English teacher.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Marta es profesora.
contents.questionSub: Marta is a teacher.
contents.hints: "Profesora" is the word used to talk about a female teacher; for a man we'd use "profesor".

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Yo soy  ______ de inglés. Y tú, ¿en qué trabajas?
contents.hints: Yo soy profesora de inglés. Y tú, ¿en qué trabajas?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the shop assistant


Example

El dependiente trabaja en la tienda.

The shop assistant works in the shop.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Hola, María, ¿qué tal? Soy Alberto y soy profesor. ¿Y tú, en qué trabajas? - Yo soy dependienta.
contents.questionSub: Marta is a teacher.
contents.hints: María is a shop assistant.

contents.title: El profesor / La profesora
contents.spanishText: How we refer to some professions changes depending on whether we talk about a man or a woman.
contents.englishText:
Luis es profesor (Luis is a teacher.)

Mi amiga es médica. (My female friend is a doctor.)

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the doctor


Example

La médica trabaja en un hospital.

The doctor works in a hospital.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Mi amigo es médico.
contents.questionSub: My female friend is a doctor.
contents.hints: My female friend is not a doctor, my male friend is.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the waiter / the waitress


Example

Antonio es camarero y trabaja en un bar.

Antonio is a waiter and he works in a bar.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the student


Example

Cristina es estudiante de francés.

Cristina is a French student.

contents.title: Choose the correct answer
contents.question: Who works with "estudiantes"?
contents.hints: the teacher

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn different professions and how to talk about yours

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Where do you work?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Bea, ¿dónde trabajas?
contents.questionSub: We use this question to ask for someone's workplace.
contents.hints: To ask about a profession we say "¿En qué trabajas?", and "¿Dónde trabajas?" to refer to the place.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Y tú, Manu, ¿  ______  trabajas?
contents.hints: Y tú, Manu, ¿dónde trabajas?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
an office


Example

Trabajo en una oficina.

I work in an office.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Mi amigo Jorge trabaja en una  ______  .
contents.hints: Mi amigo Jorge trabaja en una oficina.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
a hospital


Example

Mi amiga Ainhoa es médica y trabaja en un hospital.

My friend Ainhoa is a doctor and she works in a hospital.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Iván es médico y trabaja en un  ______
contents.hints: Iván es médico y trabaja en un hospital.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
a restaurant


Example

Soy camarero y trabajo en un restaurante.

I'm a waiter and I work in a restaurant.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
a shop


Example

Mi amiga Carmen es dependienta y trabaja en una tienda.

My friend Carmen is a shop assistant and she works in a shop.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: David es dependiente en una  ______  de ordenadores.
contents.hints: David es dependiente en una tienda de ordenadores.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Practise your conversation skills

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Imagine that you meet someone at a party. How do you ask about their workplace?
contents.hints: Where do you work?

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Soy médico y trabajo  ______  un  ______
contents.hints: I'm a doctor and I work in a hospital.

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: Soy dependienta y trabajo en una tienda.
contents.correctAnswer: Soy, dependienta, y, trabajo, en, una, tienda.

contents.title: choose the correct answer
contents.question: At a party, someone asks your friend María what she does and where. She says...
contents.hints: I'm a doctor, I work in a hospital.
options: Soy médico; trabaja en un hospital.
Soy médica; trabajo en un hospital.
contents.correctAnswer: Soy médica; trabajo en un hospital.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn words to refer to specific things or things we know

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Definite articles are the words that we place before a specific item (noun) that is known and can be identified by us. Definite articles agree in gender and number with the noun they precede.
contents.englishText:
In Spanish the definite articles are:

el/los (masculine)
la/las (feminine)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: la enfermera
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are feminine and singular.
contents.hints: It has the article "la", used for feminine nouns. The word "enfermera" (nurse) also ends in -a.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el abogado
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are feminine and singular.
contents.hints: It's a masculine word because it has the article "el", and "abogado" (laywer) also ends in "-o".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: la médica
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are feminine and singular.
contents.hints: It has the article "la", used for feminine nouns, and the word "médica" also ends in -a.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el estudiante
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are masculine and singular.
contents.hints: Although "estudiante" is used in the masculine and feminine, here it's masculine because it has "el".

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Words ending in -e or -ista can be either masculine or feminine.
contents.englishText: estudiante, periodista, etc.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el periodista
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are masculine and singular.
contents.hints: Although "periodista" is used in the masculine and feminine, here it's masculine because it has "el".

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: For masculine words that end with a consonant, the letter a is added to change it to feminine.
contents.englishText: el profesor, la profesora

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el profesor
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are masculine and singular.
contents.hints: It's a masculine word because it has the article "el".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: las profesoras
contents.questionSub: This phrase refers to more than one individual.
contents.hints: It uses the article "las" (the, feminine plural) with the noun "profesoras" (female teachers).

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: los estudiantes
contents.questionSub: This phrase refers to more than one individual.
contents.hints: It uses the article "los" (masculine and plural) with the noun "students".

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn words to refer to general or unknown things

contents.title:
Here's a tip!

 Let's compare two sentences:
contents.spanishText: El camarero trabaja en un restaurante. (The waiter works in a restaurant.)
contents.englishText: El camarero trabaja en el restaurante de la esquina. (The waiter works in the restaurant on the corner.)

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Imagine a city where we have many restaurants and then imagine a waiter in this city. You know that waiters work in restaurants but the waiter in particular we are talking about works in a specific restaurant; the restaurant on the corner.
contents.englishText:
In the first sentence we talk about a waiter working at a restaurant (any restaurant): 

El camarero trabaja en un restaurante. (The waiter works in a restaurant.)


In the second sentence we talk about this waiter working at the restaurant on the corner (a specific restaurant): 

El camarero trabaja en el restaurante de la esquina. (The waiter works in the restaurant on the corner.)

contents.title: Select the correct answer
contents.question: Choose the articles in the sentence.
contents.hints: "El" is the definite singular masculine article and "un" is the indefinite singular masculine article.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We use definite articles "el, la, los, las" to talk about a specific thing, place or person that we know or we have heard about before.
contents.englishText:
Ana es la actriz principal. (Ana is the leading actress.)


Carlos trabaja en el restaurante de la esquina. (Carlos works in the restaurant on the corner.)

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: In contrast to definite articles, we use indefinite articles to introduce something for the first time or talk about non-specific things, places or people.
contents.englishText: Necesito encontrar un hospital. (I need to find a hospital.) > Any hospital.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: El profesor de español.
contents.questionSub: This person is known to the speaker and listener.
contents.hints: This person is known to the speaker because she uses "el" to refer to a specific teacher.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: El médico trabaja en un hospital.
contents.questionSub: This statement talks about a specific place.
contents.hints: It talks about a hospital (any hospital) in general.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Necesito encontrar un hospital.
contents.questionSub: The article in bold refers to a specific place.
contents.hints: This sentence means "I need to find a hospital". The indefinite article un indicates that is a non-specific place.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: La profesora enseña español en una escuela.
contents.questionSub: The article in bold refers to a non-specific place.
contents.hints: With "una" we're referring to "any school", without highlighting a specific one.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText:
Did you notice?
If the noun is feminine and singular "escuela" (school) , then its article also has to be feminine and singular "una escuela". If that same noun becomes plural "escuelas" (schools) the article also becomes plural "unas escuelas".
contents.englishText:
This is the same for masculine singular and masculine plural nouns.
un hospital (a hospital) > unos hospitales (hospitals)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Nosotros trabajamos en una oficina.
contents.questionSub: The indefinite article in the sentence is feminine and singular.
contents.hints: "Una" is the feminine singular indefinite article; "un" would be the masculine form.

contents.hints: I'm a doctor and I work in a hospital.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: la enfermera
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are feminine and singular.
contents.hints: It has the article "la", used for feminine nouns. The word "enfermera" (nurse) also ends in -a.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: la médica
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are feminine and singular.
contents.hints: It has the article "la", used for feminine nouns, and the word "médica" also ends in -a.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el periodista
contents.questionSub: The words in this phrase are masculine and singular.
contents.hints: Although "periodista" is used in the masculine and feminine, here it's masculine because it has "el".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: los estudiantes
contents.questionSub: This phrase refers to more than one individual.
contents.hints: It uses the article "los" (masculine and plural) with the noun "students".

contents.title: Select the correct answer

contents.hints: "El" is the definite singular masculine article and "un" is the indefinite singular masculine article.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Nosotros trabajamos en una oficina.

contents.hints: "Una" is the feminine singular indefinite article; "un" would be the masculine form.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn words to talk about different people in your relatives

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the mother

Example


¿Cuántos hermanos tiene tu madre?

How many siblings does your mother have?

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the father

Example


Mi padre tiene una hermana.

My father has one sister.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: It is also common to say "mamá" and "papá" instead of "madre" and "padre".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el padre
contents.questionSub: This means "the mother".
contents.hints: This means "the father".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the son / the daughter

Example


Su hijo tiene dos años y su hija tiene tres meses.

His / her son is two years old and his / her daughter is three months old.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the brother / the sister

Example


Tu hermano tiene cinco amigos.

Your brother has five friends.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Click on the two family members.
contents.hints: Carmen, ¿en qué trabajas?

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.hints: The audio says "el hijo / la hija". "Hijo" is a masculine word, and "hija" is feminine.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the grandfather / the grandmother

Example


Mi abuela tiene siete gatos.

My grandmother has seven cats.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the grandson / the granddaughter 


Example

Nuestro nieto vive en España.

Our grandson lives in Spain.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: el nieto / la nieta
contents.questionSub: This means "the grandfather / the grandmother".
contents.hints: This means "the grandson / the granddaughter".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the uncle / the aunt 


Example

Tu tía tiene los ojos azules.

Your aunt has blue eyes.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
the cousin


Example

Su primo tiene diez años.

Their cousin is ten years old.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.hints: the uncle / the aunt

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Use words like "mi, tu, su..." to express possession

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We use possessive adjectives to indicate to whom or to what something or someone belongs. We write them before the thing or person owned.
contents.englishText:
Mi padre tiene una hermana. (My father has a sister.)


Nuestro nieto vive en España. (Our grandson lives in Spain.)

contents.title: Order the words correctly in a sentence.
contents.hints: My father has one sister.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Every personal pronoun has a matching possessive adjective.
contents.englishText:
yo > mi (my)  

Mi abuela tiene siete gatos.


tú > tu (your)

Tu hermano tiene cinco amigos.


él / ella / usted> su (his / her) 

Su primo tiene diez años.


nosotros / nosotras> nuestro / nuestra (our) 

Nuestro nieto vive en España.


vosotros / vosotras > vuestro / vuestra (your) 

Vuestra tía tiene los ojos azules.


ellos / ellas / ustedes> su (their)

Su hijo tiene dos años y su hija tiene tres meses.

contents.title: Choose the correct answer
contents.question: Choose the possessive adjective.
contents.hints: Su

contents.title: Choose the correct answer
contents.question: Choose the possessive adjective.
contents.hints: "Tu" is the possesive adjective for "tú" (you, informal).

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Carmen vive con su madre.
contents.questionSub: The possessive adjective in bold means "her".
contents.hints: Remember that we use "su" to talk both about male (his) and female (her).

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Nuestro nieto vive en España.
contents.questionSub: The possessive adjective in bold means "our".
contents.hints: In this case, we're referring to something or someone masculine, because we're using "nuestro".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Vuestra tía tiene los ojos azules.
contents.questionSub: The possessive adjective in bold means "your" and it is masculine.
contents.hints: It means "your" and it is feminine.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Juan y Antonio viven con su hermano.
contents.questionSub: The possessive adjective in bold is masculine and singular.
contents.hints: Remember that "su" can also refer to someone or something feminine.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn the numbers from 0 to 10 in Spanish

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
one, two, three...


Mis dos hermanas son rubias.

My two sisters are blonde

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText:
"Un, uno, una" can mean a/an or one:

"Una" is feminine.

"Un" and "uno" are both masculine. > We use "un" before masculine singular nouns. We use "uno" when we don't need to use a noun after it.
contents.englishText:
Tengo una nieta. (I have one granddaughter)


Tengo un hermano. (I have one brother.)


¿Cuántos hermanos tienes? Tengo uno. (How many brothers do you have? I have one.)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: dos
contents.questionSub: This means "two".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.hints: one

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
four, five, six...


Example

Vuestros cuatro hijos son muy guapos.

Your four children are very handsome.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Listen the audio carefully
contents.hints: The audio says "cuatro", which means "four".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
seven, eight


Example

Sus ocho primos viven en España.

Their eight cousins live in Spain.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: siete
contents.questionSub: This means "six".
contents.hints: This means "seven".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
nine, ten


Example

Antonio y yo tenemos diez nietos.

Antonio and I have ten grandchildren.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Choose the phrase that matches the audio

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn and practise the present simple of "tener" (to have)

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Remember: We use the verb "tener" (to have) when talking or asking about someone's age.
contents.englishText: ¿Cuántos años tiene tu madre? (How old is your mother?)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Su hijo tiene dos años y su hija tiene tres meses.
contents.questionSub: This sentence talks about just one person's age.
contents.hints: The audio mentions "su hijo" (her son) and "su hija" (her daughter), so it talks about two people.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We also use "tener" (to have) to indicate a family relationship and to talk about possession.
contents.englishText: Mi padre tiene una hermana. (My father has a sister.)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Tengo dos hermanas y un hermano.
contents.questionSub: "Tener" in this sentence indicates a family relationship.
contents.hints: She mentions her family, saying: "Tengo dos hermanas y un hermano." (I have 2 sisters and 1 brother.)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Vuestra tía tiene los ojos azules.
contents.questionSub: "Tener" in this sentence indicates a family relationship.
contents.hints: Remember: We also use tener for describing parts of the body.

contents.title: Grammar: Tener (to have)
contents.spanishText: The verb "tener" (to have) is irregular because it does not follow the same pattern in formation as other, regular verbs. The singular forms of the "presente simple" of the verb "tener" are:
contents.englishText: The provided table demonstrates the conjugation of the Spanish verb "tener" (to have) in the present tense, paired with its corresponding personal pronouns. "Yo" (I) takes the form "tengo" (I have), "tú" (you, informal) becomes "tienes" (you have), and "él/ella/usted" (he/she/you, formal) uses "tiene" (he/she/you have). This illustrates how Spanish verbs change form to agree with the subject pronoun, showing who is performing the action of "having."

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Yo tengo una hermana.
contents.questionSub: This sentence indicates the family relationship that one person has.
contents.hints: She says: "Yo tengo una hermana." (I have one sister.)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Mi hermana tiene cinco hijos.
contents.questionSub: This sentence indicates the family relationship that one person has.
contents.hints: The audio says: "Mi hermana tiene cinco hijos." (My sister has five children.)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Tus padres tienen muchos nietos.
contents.questionSub: This sentence indicates the family relationship that one person has.
contents.hints: "Tus padres" refers to "They" and it indicates the relationship of more than person.

contents.title: Grammar: Tener (to have)
contents.spanishText: The plural forms of the verb "tener" are:
contents.englishText: This table shows the plural conjugations of the Spanish verb "tener" (to have) in the present tense, demonstrating how it changes based on the plural subject pronouns: "nosotros/nosotras" (we) uses "tenemos" (we have), "vosotros/vosotras" (you all, informal) uses "tenéis" (you all have), and "ellos/ellas/ustedes" (they/you all, formal) uses "tienen" (they/you all have).

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Cuántos hermanos o hermanas tenéis?
contents.questionSub: This sentence indicates the family relationship that more than one person has.
contents.hints: She uses "tenéis", which is the "vosotros" form for "tener", so she refers to more than one person.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: In some Latin American countries, such as Argentina, Chile and Peru, "cartera" means "bag" and not "wallet". In these countries, the words "billetera" and "monedero" are used instead of "cartera". "Billetera" is commonly used to refer to a wallet in general, whereas "monedero" is specifically used to refer to a small coin purse.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText:
Colours, in Spanish, have a singular and a plural form depending on the noun they are describing. Their gender also changes according to the noun.

However, there are some exceptions:

azul, verde, naranja, rosa and gris are the same for masculine and feminine. They only change from singular to plural.
contents.englishText:
Estas gafas negras son bonitas. (These black glasses are beautiful.)


Aquellos móviles negros son muy viejos. (Those black phones over there are very old.)


El reloj naranja es el mío. (The orange watch is mine.)

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Talk about belongings using possessive pronouns

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We use possessive adjectives to express possession or relationships. They are placed before the object or person in a sentence.
contents.englishText:
Mi abuela tiene el pelo gris. (My grandmother has grey hair.)


Tus llaves son pequeñas. (Your keys are small.)


Nuestro nieto vive en España. (Our grandson lives in Spain.)

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Each possessive adjective has an equivalent possessive pronoun. These work in a similar way, but in a sentence, they replace the object / person they describe, rather than accompanying it.
contents.englishText:
yo > mi > el mío / la mía


tú > tu > el tuyo / la tuya


él / ella / usted > su > el suyo / la suya


nosotros / nosotras > nuestro / nuestra > el nuestro / la nuestra


vosotros / vosotras > vuestro / vuestra > el vuestro / la vuestra


ellos / ellas / ustedes > su > el suyo / la suya

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Es esta cartera marrón la tuya?
contents.questionSub: The word in bold is a possessive adjective.
contents.hints: It is a possessive pronoun as "la tuya" (yours) is replacing the object "cartera" (wallet).

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Tienes mi bolso? Este no es "el mío".
contents.questionSub: The word in bold is a possessive pronoun.
contents.hints: Mi abuela tiene el pelo gris. (My grandmother has grey hair.)

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: In Spanish, possessive pronouns can be made up of more than one word. e.g. el suyo. The singular possessive pronouns in Spanish are:
contents.englishText:
el mío / la mía (mine)


el tuyo / la tuya (yours belonging to "tú")


el suyo / la suya (his, hers, its, yours belonging to "usted")


el nuestro / la nuestra (ours)


el vuestro / la vuestra (yours belonging to "vosotros / vosotras")


el suyo / la suya (theirs, yours (belonging to "ustedes"))

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Tienes mi bolso? Este no es "el mío".
contents.questionSub: The possessive pronoun in bold means "mine".
contents.hints: "El mío" (mine) refers to something singular and masculine. In this case, "el bolso" (the bag).

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We use possessive pronouns to avoid repetition. In the example below, the second sentence is much more natural.
contents.englishText:
Este bolso no es mi bolso. > Este no es el mío.
(This bag is not my bag. > This is not mine.)

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Mi tía tiene los ojos azules. La vuestra tiene los ojos marrones.
contents.questionSub: The possessive pronoun in bold means "yours" (belonging to "tú").
contents.hints: It means "yours" belonging to "vosotros / vosotras".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: No me gusta este bolso rojo, prefiero el suyo.
contents.questionSub: The possessive pronoun in bold is masculine and singular.
contents.hints: "El suyo" refers to his or hers, and it's masculine singular. If it were plural it'd be "los suyos".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: No me gustan estos bolsos rojos, prefiero los suyos.
contents.questionSub: The possessive pronoun in bold is masculine and singular.
contents.hints: The possessive pronoun in bold is masculine and plural.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.

contents.hints: "Esta" is used to talk about feminine and singular things that are close to us; here, "la cartera".

contents.title: ¿Este o esta?
contents.spanishText: Have you noticed? We use "este" with masculine words and "esta" with feminine words.

contents.hints: "Estos" (masculine, plural) is the plural of "este" (masculine, singular). "Estes" doesn't exist.

contents.title: True or false?

contents.hints: He's talking about more than one book because he's using "estos" (these).

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText:
these... (feminine)

Example


¿Te gustan estas gafas de sol?

Do you like these sunglasses?

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: ¿De quién son ______ llaves?
contents.hints: "Estas" is used to talk about feminine and plural things that are close to us; here, "las llaves".

contents.title: ¿Este o esta?
contents.spanishText: Have you noticed? We use "estos" with masculine plural words and "estas" with feminine plural words.
contents.englishText:
estos teléfonos (these phones), estos amigos (these friends)


estas gafas de sol (these sunglasses), estas llaves (these keys)

contents.title: Look, something new!

contents.englishText: I usually have coffee in a café.

lessons.lessonTitle: Expanding the knowledge of places around town
lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn more words to refer to places in a town

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Where is there a bus stop?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Dónde hay una parada de autobús?

contents.title: Choose the correct option.

contents.questionSub: Jesús is looking for a bus stop.
contents.hints: He's looking for a train station (estación de tren) and not a bus stop (parada de autobús).

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We can take the "tren" (train) or "metro" (metro) at the "estación" (station). We usually take the "autobús" or "bus" (bus) at the "parada" (stop).

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: La ___  de ___  está en el centro.
contents.hints: The correct spelling for train station is "estación de tren", even if in some regions the "c" sounds like "s".

contents.title: Look, something new!

contents.title: True or false?

contents.hints: He's asking about the "hospital", not the train station.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Perdona, ¿dónde está el ______ ?
contents.hints: Even if the "h" at the beginning is not pronounced, we write "hospital".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Where can we take the train?
contents.hints: We get the train at the "estación", the bus at the "parada" and we go to the "hospital" when we're sick.

lessons.lessonTitle: Asking about places in a city
lessons.lessonSubTitle: Listen a audio where Susan asks about places in a city

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Susan is visiting Madrid and she gets lost. Watch how she asks about a market!
contents.englishText:
Susan: ¡Hola!
Carmen: ¡Hola!
Susan: Perdona, ¿hay un mercado por aquí?
Carmen: Mmmm, no, lo siento, no hay un mercado, pero hay una tienda en esta calle.
Susan: Vale, muchas gracias.
Carmen: mmmm, mira, hay un mercado muy famoso, pero está en el centro. Puedes ir en autobús o en metro.
Susan: ¡Perfecto! ¿Dónde hay una parada de autobús?
Carmen: Hay una parada de autobús allí, al lado de la cafetería y también hay una estación de metro al final de esta calle.
Susan: Vale, muchas gracias.
Carmen: ¡De nada!

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: What is Susan looking for?
contents.hints: Although we can also buy things in a "tienda", Susan explicitely asks for "un mercado".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Dónde hay una parada de autobús?
contents.questionSub: There's a market on this street.
contents.hints: Carmen says "no hay mercados", because the market is in the city centre. But there is a shop on the street.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: How do you ask somebody: "Is there a market around here?"
contents.hints: The correct way to ask this is "hay+ un/una + place".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: En esta calle hay una ______ .
contents.hints: There is a shop on this street.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Mmmm, hay un mercado muy famoso en el centro. Puedes ir en autobús o en metro.
contents.questionSub: There's a market in the city centre.
contents.hints: Carmen says "hay un mercado muy famoso en el centro".

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: ¿Dónde hay una parada de autobús? :- Where is there a bus stop?

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Hay una estación de metro ______ .
contents.hints: There's a market in the centre, but a metro station at the end of the street.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Talk about the existence of things, people and places

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: En mi barrio hay un hospital.
contents.englishText: There is a hospital in my neighbourhood.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Dónde hay una parada de autobús?
contents.questionSub: There is a hospital in Raquel's neighbourhood.
contents.hints: She uses "hay" to express what there is and she mentions "un hospital".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: En mi barrio ______ un hospital.
contents.hints: Even if the "h" at the beginning is not pronounced, we write "hay".

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: En esta calle hay una cafetería.
contents.correctAnswer: En, esta calle, hay, una cafetería.

contents.title: Hay...
contents.spanishText: "Hay" (there is/there are) can be followed by masculine and feminine words:
contents.englishText:
En mi barrio hay un hospital. (There is a hospital in my neighbourhood.)


En esta calle hay una cafetería. (There is a café on this street.)

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: En esta calle no hay muchas cafeterías.
contents.englishText: There are not many cafés on this street.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: En este barrio ___ ___ mercados.
contents.hints: The correct spelling for "there is" is "hay", and "mercados" is masculine so we need "muchos" instead of "muchas".

contents.title: hay (there is / there are)
contents.spanishText: Good news! "Hay" never changes, it can be used to say there is one thing or there are many things.
contents.englishText:
En este barrio hay un mercado. (There is a market in this neighbourhood.)


En este barrio hay muchos mercados. (There are many markets in this neighbourhood.)

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: En esta calle no hay muchas cafeterías.
contents.englishText: There are no train stations in this neighbourhood.

contents.title: Complete the sentence to say that there are no train stations.
contents.question: ______ estaciones de tren en este barrio.
contents.hints: To express what there isn't or what there aren't, we use "no hay" and then the object.

contents.title: No hay...
contents.spanishText: In order to express what there isn't or there aren't we also use "hay". We add "no" before "hay" to express what there isn't or there aren't.
contents.englishText:
No hay estaciones de tren en este barrio. (There are no train stations in this neighbourhood).


No hay muchas cafeterías en esta calle. (There aren't many cafés on this street).

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Is there a hospital around here?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Hola, perdona, ¿hay un hospital por aquí?
contents.questionSub: Adrián knows that there is a hospital in the area.
contents.hints: He doesn't know for sure, he is just asking if there's a hospital around.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Read a text and discover Carolina's neighbourhood

contents.title: Read this text of Carolina talking about her neighbourhood.
contents.spanishText: ¡Hola! Me llamo Carolina y vivo en Madrid. Mi barrio es fantástico porque hay muchas cosas. Por ejemplo, hay un mercado donde compro comida. También hay muchas cafeterías, ¡todos los días tomo café allí! Hay muchas tiendas de ropa, música, libros... Además, hay muchas paradas de autobús y una estación de tren. Pero no hay hospitales. Todos mis amigos y mi familia viven aquí, ¡y es fantástico!

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Mi barrio es fantástico porque hay muchas cosas.
contents.questionSub: There are many things in the area where Carolina lives.
contents.hints: She says "hay muchas cosas" and also "es fantástico" (it's great).

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Me encanta mi barrio porque ______ muchas cosas.
contents.hints: Even if the "h" at the beginning is not pronounced, we write "hay".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Hay un mercado donde compro comida.
contents.questionSub: There are three markets in Carolina's neighbourhood.
contents.hints: She says there is one market (un mercado), but not three (tres mercados).

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Pero no hay hospitales.
contents.questionSub: There's a hospital in Carolina's neighbourhood.
contents.hints: She mentions that "no hay hospitales" (there aren't any hospitals).

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Carolina siempre toma café en las ______ de su barrio.
contents.hints: We can have breakfast in a café (cafetería) but not in a bus stop (parada de autobús).

contents.title: Choose the correct answer
contents.question: What does Carolina do at the "mercado"?
contents.hints: She has coffee (tomar café) in the cafés (cafeterías) and she buys books in the shops (tiendas).

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: Mi barrio es fantástico porque hay muchas cosas. :- My neighbourhood is fantastic because it has many things.
contents.correctAnswer: Mi, barrio, es fantástico, porque, hay, muchas cosas.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Put your skills to the test

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Normalmente tomo café en una cafetería.
contents.questionSub: Virginia usually drinks coffee at home.
contents.hints: She says she usually has coffee in a café (una cafetería) and not at home (en casa).

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Compro en el  ______ .
contents.hints: In a "mercado" (not "mercato") we find different stalls selling fruit, meat, fish, etc.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Where can we have a coffee?
contents.hints: We usually buy things (food, clothes, gifts, etc.) in the "tienda" or "mercado".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: ¿Dónde hay una ______ de autobús?
contents.hints: The correct spelling for the word for "bus stop" is "parada de autobús".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Dónde hay una estación de tren?
contents.questionSub: Jesús is looking for a bus stop.
contents.hints: He's looking for a train station (estación de tren) and not a bus stop (parada de autobús).

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: La ___  de ___  está en el centro.
contents.hints: The correct spelling for train station is "estación de tren", even if in some regions the "c" sounds like "s".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: How do you ask somebody: "Is there a market around here?"
contents.hints: The correct way to ask this is "hay+ un/una + place".

contents.title: Complete the sentence to say that there are no train stations.
contents.question: ______ estaciones de tren en este barrio.
contents.hints: To express what there isn't or what there aren't, we use "no hay" and then the object.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Carolina siempre toma café en las ______ de su barrio.
contents.hints: We can have breakfast in a café (cafetería) but not in a bus stop (parada de autobús).

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints: Mi barrio es fantástico porque hay muchas cosas. :- My neighbourhood is fantastic because it has many things.
contents.correctAnswer: Mi, barrio, es fantástico, porque, hay, muchas cosas.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Ask for and give directions in Spanish

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Where is the station?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Dónde está la estación?
contents.questionSub: We use "¿dónde está...?" to ask about the location of a place.
contents.hints: We use "¿dónde está...?" followed by the name of the place to find out its location.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: ¿Dónde ______ la estación?
contents.hints: We use "está" to talk about location and "es" to describe something.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: go straight ahead

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Sigue recto.
contents.questionSub: David is indicating to turn right.
contents.hints: He's telling someone to go straight ahead ("sigue recto").

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: cross the street

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: ______ la calle.
contents.hints: Although in some countries this will be pronounced as "s", "cruza" is spelled with "z".

contents.title: Select the languages in the order you hear them.
contents.question: Sigue ___ y ___ la calle.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: turn right

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Gira a la derecha.
contents.questionSub: Pedro is indicating to turn left.
contents.hints: He's telling someone to turn right ("gira a la derecha").

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Gira a la ______ .
contents.hints: The correct spelling for the word for "right" is "derecha".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: turn left

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: at the end of the street

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Use adverbs to talk about location

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: La cafetería está cerca del hospital.
contents.englishText: The café is close to the hospital.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: La cafetería está cerca del hospital.
contents.questionSub: The café is far away from the hospital.
contents.hints: The café is "cerca", that is, close to the hospital.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: ¿Hay un hospital ______ de aquí?
contents.hints: Although in some countries the first "c" will be pronounced as "s", "cerca" is spelled with a "c".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: El mercado está lejos de la estación.
contents.englishText: The market is far from the station.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: El mercado está ______ de la estación.
contents.hints: The correct spelling of the word that says something is far away is "lejos".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: La parada de autobús está lejos de la tienda.
contents.questionSub: The shop is close to the bus stop.
contents.hints: The bus stop is "lejos" (far away) from the shop, and not "cerca" (close to).

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: La cafetería está enfrente del mercado.
contents.englishText: The café is in front of the market.

contents.title: Complete the sentence to say that the café is in front of the market.
contents.question: La cafetería está  ______ del mercado.
contents.hints: "Enfrente de" means "in front of", but "lejos" means "far from".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: La tienda está al lado de la estación.
contents.englishText: The shop is next to the station.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: La tienda está al lado de la estación de metro.
contents.questionSub: The metro station is next to the shop.
contents.hints: The shop is "al lado de", that means it is next to the metro station.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn how to use "hay" and "está" to talk about places

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: En mi barrio hay muchas tiendas.
contents.englishText: There are many shops in my neighbourhood.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: En mi barrio hay muchas tiendas.
contents.questionSub: We use "hay" to say "there is" or "there are".
contents.hints: "Hay" can be used for both singular and plural.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: En mi barrio ______ muchas tiendas.
contents.hints: Even if the "h" at the beginning is not pronounced, we write "hay".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Where is the hospital?

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: La tienda está al lado de la estación de metro.
contents.questionSub: We use "está" to say where something is located.
contents.hints: We use "está" to express the location of something.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: La tienda ______  al lado de la estación.
contents.hints: Accents matter! "Está" introduces a location, and "esta" means "this".

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Read a text about someone's new life in Mexico City

contents.title: Listen to the audio.
contents.spanishText: Mi vida en Ciudad de México
contents.englishText:
Hola, Luis:

¿Qué tal? Yo estoy muy contenta porque ahora vivo en Ciudad de México con mi hermana. Es una ciudad muy grande y muy bella. Vivimos en el centro, y hay muchas cafeterías, restaurantes y mercados cerca. Mi mercado favorito es el Mercado de San Juan. Está enfrente de nuestra casa.

Trabajo en una escuela en el centro, donde soy profesora de español. Hay una cafetería muy buena al lado de la escuela. Se llama Cafebrería el Péndulo. El camarero se llama Antonio. Es mi amigo y es muy simpático, y muy guapo también. Voy allí todos los días después de trabajar. Tomo un café y una torta de jamón (¡mi favorita!), y leo un libro. ¡Hay muchos libros en esta cafetería!

¡Hasta pronto!

Laura

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: Laura ___ muy ___ porque vive en México.
contents.hints: Laura is very happy because she's living in Mexico.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Hay una cafetería muy buena y voy allí todos los días.
contents.englishText: There is a very good cafe and I go there every day.

contents.title: Complete the sentence.
contents.question: ___ ___ cafetería muy buena.
contents.hints:
Hay una cafetería muy buena.
There is a very good cafe.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Tomo un café y una torta de jamón.
contents.englishText: I have a coffee and a ham sandwich.

contents.title: Put the words in order.
contents.hints:
Tomo un café y una torta de jamón.
I have a coffee and a ham sandwich.
contents.correctAnswer: Tomo, un, café, y una, torta, de jamón.

contents.title: Read the text.
contents.englishText:
¿Qué tal? Yo estoy muy contenta porque ahora vivo en Ciudad de México con mi hermana. Es una ciudad muy grande y muy bella. Vivimos en el centro, y hay muchas cafeterías, restaurantes y mercados cerca. Mi mercado favorito es el Mercado de San Juan. Está enfrente de nuestra casa.

Trabajo en una escuela en el centro, donde soy profesora de español. Hay una cafetería muy buena al lado de la escuela. Se llama Cafebrería el Péndulo. El camarero se llama Antonio. Es mi amigo y es muy simpático, y muy guapo también. Voy allí todos los días después de trabajar. Tomo un café y una torta de jamón (¡mi favorita!), y leo un libro. ¡Hay muchos libros en esta cafetería!

¡Hasta pronto!

Laura

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Laura's favourite market is...
contents.hints: opposite her house.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Select the sentence that is grammatically correct.
contents.hints:
El mercado está enfrente de nuestra casa.
The market is in front of our house.
options: El mercado está enfrente de nuestra casa.
El mercado está enfrente nuestra casa.
El mercado está enfrente a nuestra casa.
contents.correctAnswer: El mercado está enfrente de nuestra casa.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn the names of some basic foods

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Tengo la lista de la compra en mi móvil.
contents.englishText: I have the shopping list on my phone.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Escribo la ______ de la compra en una app en mi móvil.
contents.hints: The document where we write what we have to buy is called a "lista de la compra" (shopping list).

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: I don't eat meat.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: It's important to eat lots of fruit.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: ¿Cuál es tu ______  favorita?
contents.hints: The general word to talk about apples, bananas, strawberries, oranges, etc. is fruit.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Compro pan para hacer un bocadillo.
contents.englishText: I buy bread to make a sandwich.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Which is the basic ingredient to prepare a sandwich?
contents.hints: A sandwich always has bread; the ingredients inside might change.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: The fish is delicious.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Si vas al restaurante Ayna, te recomiendo el pescado.
contents.questionSub: The meat is good in this restaurant.
contents.hints: The audio says "te recomiendo el pescado" (I recommend the fish); it doesn't mention meat.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: En este restaurante el ______ es muy bueno.
contents.hints: Watch out! "Carne" (meat) ends in "-e" but it's a feminine word: la carne.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: I love vegetables!

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn the names of different stores where you can buy food

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: I buy fruit in the fruit shop.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Compro fruta en la frutería.
contents.questionSub: We can buy fruit in that place.
contents.hints: In the "frutería" we can buy "fruta" (fruit) and "verduras" (vegetables).

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Compro el pan en la panadería.
contents.englishText: I buy bread in the bakery.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Compro el pan en la ______ .
contents.hints: Watch out! The correct spelling for the word for "bakery" is "panadería".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Perdona, ¿hay una panadería por aquí?
contents.questionSub: Ramón wants to buy fruit.
contents.hints: He wants to buy bread, since he's looking for a "panadería" (bakery) and not a "frutería".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: We buy meat at the butcher's.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Compramos carne en la ______ .
contents.hints: Tricky spelling! The product is "carne", with an "-e", but a butcher's is "carnicería", with an "-i".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Hay una pescadería en el mercado.
contents.englishText: There's a fishmonger's in the market.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Compro pescado en la ______ .
contents.hints: We buy "carne" (meat) in the "carnicería" but "pescado" (fish) in the "pescadería".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: I buy books at the bookstore.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Compro libros en la ______ de mi barrio.
contents.hints: We buy "pan" (bread) in the "panadería" but "libros" (books) in the "librería".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: I buy everything at the supermarket.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Si vas al restaurante Ayna, te recomiendo el pescado.
contents.questionSub: The meat is good in this restaurant.
contents.hints: The audio says "te recomiendo el pescado" (I recommend the fish); it doesn't mention meat.

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn the names of some basic foods and traditional dishes

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: Un café con leche, por favor.
contents.englishText: A coffee with milk, please.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Un café con leche, por favor.
contents.questionSub: María orders a coffee with milk.
contents.hints: She says "con leche", and "leche" is the word for "milk".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: I have my coffee with sugar.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Tomo el café con ______ .
contents.hints: Even though in some regions this word is pronounced with an "s", this is the correct spelling for "azúcar" (sugar).

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Paella contains rice.

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.englishText: Paella is one of the most traditional dishes in Spain. It originally comes from Valencia, in the East, but it's prepared all over the Spanish territory. It can have fish, meat, chicken, vegetables, etc. but don't add chorizo if you don't want to make your Spanish friends angry!

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: La paella lleva ______ .
contents.hints: "Arroz" is spelled with a double "r". The sound is much stronger than the sound of a single "r".

contents.title: Look, something new!
contents.spanishText: La tortilla española lleva muchos huevos.
contents.englishText: Spanish omelette has lots of eggs.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: La tortilla española lleva muchos ______ .
contents.hints: Watch out! Although these two words might sound similar, the correct spelling for eggs is "huevos".

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Talk about foods and quantities

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: In Spanish there are some nouns that can be counted using numbers. We call them "contables" (countable).
contents.englishText: una manzana, dos bolígrafos, cuatro huevos, etc. : an apple, two pens, four eggs, etc.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Podría pasarme un poco de azúcar?
contents.questionSub: The noun in bold is countable.
contents.hints: In Spanish, we cannot count "sugar" using numbers.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Click on the countable noun.
contents.hints: We can count apples: una manzana, cinco manzanas, etc. but not "azúcar" (sugar) nor "leche" (milk).

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: There are some nouns that we cannot count using numbers. These are called "incontables" (uncountable). To define the quantity of these nouns we use other words like "kilo / litre", or "a bottle / a piece / a packet" etc.
contents.englishText:
un kilo de azúcar / un paquete de azúcar : a kilo of sugar / a pack of sugar


un litro de leche / un cartón de leche : a litre of milk / a carton of milk

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Necesito un paquete de arroz, no queda mucho.
contents.questionSub: The noun in bold is countable.
contents.hints: We count the container or the quantity of rice, we can even count a grain of rice but not the rice itself.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Click on the uncountable noun
contents.hints: We can count both "huevos" and "naranjas" (cinco naranjas, diez huevos, etc.) but not "leche" (milk).

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Quedan 250 gramos de pasta, ¿te parece suficiente?
contents.questionSub: The noun in bold is uncountable.
contents.hints: We can count the grams of pasta, but we can't say "una pasta, cinco pastas, veinte pastas", etc.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Podría pasarme un poco de azúcar?
contents.questionSub: The noun in bold is countable.
contents.hints: In Spanish, we cannot count "sugar" using numbers.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Necesito un paquete de arroz, no queda mucho
contents.questionSub: The noun in bold is countable.
contents.hints: We count the container or the quantity of rice, we can even count a grain of rice but not the rice itself.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We say "un litro de leche, aceite o vino" (a litre of milk, oil or wine) but if we want to indicate the quantity / measure of the bottle we say "una botella de un litro" (one litre bottle) or "una botella de medio litro" (half a litre bottle).

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: We say "un paquete de arroz, pasta o azúcar" (a pack of rice, pasta or sugar) but if we want to indicate the measure of the pack we say "un paquete de un kilo o un paquete de 500 gramos" (a kilo pack or a 500 grams pack).

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Learn to express quantity

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText:
Sometimes we need to express exact amounts of something: three apples, a dozen of eggs or a kilo of fruit.

Sometimes we don't know the exact amount or we just don't wish to express it. In these cases, we use a type of word called “cuantificadores indefinidos” (indefinite quantifiers).
contents.englishText:
¿Podría pasarme un poco de azúcar? - Could you pass me a bit of sugar?


La comida está salada, tiene mucha sal. - The food is salty, it's got lots of salt.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: ¿Podría pasarme un poco de azúcar?
contents.questionSub: The word in bold is describing an indefinite quantity.
contents.hints: It is specifying a specific amount; a pack.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText:
Some of the indefinite quantifiers we have in Spanish are:

poco / poca, mucho / mucha, bastante, demasiado / demasiada (a little / a lot / enough / too much)
contents.englishText:
¿Podría pasarme un poco de azúcar? - Could you pass me a bit of sugar?


Los doctores recomiendan comer mucha fruta. - Doctors recommend eating lots of fruit.


Tenemos bastante verdura. - We have enough vegetables.


Comes demasiada carne. - You eat too much meat.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Comes ______ carne.
contents.hints: This person eats much more meat than needed. Since "carne" is feminine, we use "demasiada".

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: Some of the indefinite quantifiers we have studied have a feminine and a masculine form. We need to use them with feminine and masculine nouns respectively.
contents.englishText: "Demasiada" (too much) goes before feminine nouns, and "mucho" (a lot) before masculine ones. Gender matters!

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Tengo muchas manzanas.
contents.questionSub: The word following the quantifier in bold is a countable noun.
contents.hints: We can count the number of apples therefore "manzanas" is a countable noun.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: When we use indefinite quantifiers with countable nouns we need to use the plural form of these indefinite quantifiers : pocos / pocas, muchos / muchas, bastantes, demasiados / demasiadas.
contents.englishText: Tengo muchas manzanas. (I have many apples.)

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Tengo ______ huevos.
contents.hints: We use "pocos/-as" with countable things (huevos, manzanas, etc.) and "poco" with uncountable things.

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Leo pocos libros.
contents.questionSub: The word following the quantifier in bold is a countable noun.
contents.hints: We can count "libros" (books) so "poco" changes accordingly; in this case, masculine and plural.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText:
The quantifiers can belong to different word categories depending on their function:

-If we are describing the amount of something, this quantifier is an adjective.

-If the function of the quantifier is modifying the meaning of the verb, this quantifier is an adverb.
contents.englishText: When describing the amount of salt in food, you'd say "mucha sal" because "sal" (salt) is a feminine noun, meaning "lots of salt." However, when "mucho" stands alone, without a noun directly after it, like in "no queda mucho," it acts as an adverb, indicating a quantity of something previously mentioned (in this case, rice) and modifying the verb "queda" (remains). So, "mucha" modifies a noun, and "mucho" can also function as an adverb.

contents.title: Here's a tip!
contents.spanishText: The easiest way of seeing if a quantifier functions as an adjective is checking if it's followed by a noun.
contents.englishText: Tenemos bastante verdura. (We have enough vegetables.)

lessons.lessonSubTitle: Put your skills to the test

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Escribo la ______ de la compra en una app en mi móvil.
contents.hints: The document where we write what we have to buy is called a "lista de la compra" (shopping list).

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Which is the basic ingredient to prepare a sandwich?
contents.hints: A sandwich always has bread; the ingredients inside might change.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: En este restaurante el ______ es muy bueno.
contents.hints: Watch out! "Carne" (meat) ends in "-e" but it's a feminine word: la carne.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Compro el pan en la ______ .
contents.hints: Watch out! The correct spelling for the word for "bakery" is "panadería".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Compro libros en la ______ de mi barrio.
contents.hints: We buy "pan" (bread) in the "panadería" but "libros" (books) in the "librería".

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Tomo el café con ______ .
contents.hints: Even though in some regions this word is pronounced with an "s", this is the correct spelling for "azúcar" (sugar).

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: La tortilla española lleva muchos ______ .
contents.hints: Watch out! Although these two words might sound similar, the correct spelling for eggs is "huevos".

contents.title: True or false?
contents.question: Necesito un paquete de arroz, no queda mucho.
contents.questionSub: The noun in bold is countable.
contents.hints: We count the container or the quantity of rice, we can even count a grain of rice but not the rice itself.

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Click on the uncountable noun
contents.hints: We can count both "huevos" and "naranjas" (cinco naranjas, diez huevos, etc.) but not "leche" (milk).

contents.title: Choose the correct option.
contents.question: Tengo ______ huevos.
contents.hints: We use "pocos/-as" with countable things (huevos, manzanas, etc.) and "poco" with uncountable things.
